Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: The mentee has a small question about terminology that isn't blocking their work.
Situation2: They guide a patient on proper usage and potential side effects of a new prescription medication.
Story: I stood behind the pharmacy counter, my white coat crisp, as I explained to Mrs. Lee how to take her new blood pressure medication. She looked anxious, so I spoke slowly, making sure she understood the side effects and what to do if she missed a dose. In the back of my mind, though, a small question about a term in the new protocol gnawed at me. As a mentee, I was supposed to reach out to my mentor whenever I had uncertainties, no matter how minor. But this question wasn’t urgent, and I didn’t want to interrupt my mentor’s busy day with something that wasn’t blocking my work. At the same time, I felt the weight of my responsibility as a pharmacist—my patient needed my full attention, and I couldn’t let my mind wander. I felt torn, caught between the expectation to be a proactive mentee and the immediate demand to be a present, attentive pharmacist. My heart raced as I tried to decide which role to prioritize in this moment.
